results.title: Alien 3
results.creator_credit: Gordon Carroll, David Giler, Walter Hill, David Fincher, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Brandywine Productions
results.brief_description: Continuing the “Alien” trilogy, Ripley’s spaceship crash lands into a maximum security work correctional facility, a monastic community, host to some of the most violent criminals in the universe -but she didn’t come alone. Once again Officer Ripley is pitted against her deadliest enemy, only this time without the aid of advanced technology or modern weapons. This video also contains a 26 minute documentary called “The Making of Alien Resurrection”, which is actually the next film in the “series” after “Alien 3”.

results.title: Alien [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Gordon Carroll, David Giler, Walter Hill and Ridley Scott
results.brief_description: A sci-fi thriller with a difference. The crew aboard the space freighter Nostromo investigate a distress call and one of the crew members brings back on board an Alien of unknown origin. In comparison to the technology dominated sterile world controlled by a computer, where no-one trusts anyone, the horror of the Alien is its very organic nature. Under Scott’s direction this film is grippingly suspensful and draws interesting parallels between the perfect inhumanity of the Alien and that of the Company. Cast includes: Sigourney Weaver, Harry Dean Stanton, John Hurt.

results.title: Alice, sweet Alice = Holy terror = Communion
results.brief_description: Alice is quite unlike other girls her age. Instead of playing with friends, she loses herself in a distorted secret world, populated by satanic rituals and occult masks. Alice is fiercely jealous of the favouritism her parents show towards her younger sister, Karen, a sibling jealousy that verges on demonic. When Alice’s sister and aunt are mysteriously murdered, Alice’s parents question the depths of their daughter’s evil intent. As the family self destructs, a priest and the police believe there are stronger forces involved and are intent on uncovering the unholy truth embodied in a seemingly normal Alice. Brooke Shields makes a brief, 10 minute appearance. Cast includes Linda Miller, Mildred Clinton, Paula Shepherd and Niles McMaster.

results.title: Alice in wonderland [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Productions, Walt Disney, Clyde Geronimi, Hamilton Luske and Wilfred Jackson
results.brief_description: Animated version of Lewis Carroll’s famous story about the delightful Alice who goes on a dream fantasy adventure where animals are like humans and everything is nonsense. Voices provided by Kathryn Beaumont, Ed Wynn, Richard Haydn and Stirling Holloway.

results.title: Alice in the cities = Alice in den Stadten
results.creator_credit: Filmverlag der Autoren, Joachim von Mengershausen and Wim Wenders
results.brief_description: Through the story of a disillusioned young photojournalist who, returning from a fruitless assignment in the States, unwittingly becomes involved in a little girl’s search for her family in the North German industrial heartland, Wenders forges a distinctly European variation on the road movie. Few films capture so evocatively the feeling of life in the 20th century technological jungle, but for all its vistas of alienation and Americanisation, “Alice in the cities” finally resolves itself into a touching, indeed moving, affirmation of human relationships in an otherwise bleak world. Cast includes Rudiger Vogler and Yella Rottlander, with a haunting musical score by Can.

results.title: Alice doesn't live here anymore
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, David Susskind, Audrey Maas and Martin Scorsese
results.brief_description: In her remarkable Academy Award winning portrayal, Ellen Burstyn stars as Alice, a recently widowed housewife who packs herself and her son into a station wagon and heads off in search of a better life. Alice travels a bumpy road - no money, nowhere jobs and not much luck. She fights back with a spirited determination, which underscores this moving, often funny tale of one woman’s struggle for self-awareness and independence. With ‘Alice Doesn’t Live Here Anymore’, director Martin Scorsese shows that he is equally at home in semi-rural surroundings as he is in the asphalt jungle of ‘Taxi Driver’. The outstanding supporting cast includes Kris Kristofferson, Jodie Foster and Harvey Keitel.

results.title: Alice and Martin = Alice et Martin
results.creator_credit: France 2 Cinema, France 3 Cinema, Studio Canal+, Les Films Alain Sarde, October Films, Alain Sarde and Andre Techine
results.brief_description: After his father’s death, twenty year old Martin (Alexis Loret) goes missing. He eventually reappears at his brother’s Paris apartment and moves in with him and his housemate Alice (Juliette Binoche). Martin finds success as a fashion model and begins a tentative sexual relationship with the shy Alice. But when Martin hears that she has fallen pregnant this results in a breakdown where the shattering truth of what occurred during his disappearance threatens to destroy him and his relationship. As Techine showed in his earlier work, “Wild Reeds”, he is a master of acute observations of human need and desire. The fractured individuals at the heart of “Alice and Martin” are all seeking solace and safety. Neither detachedly bleak nor fashionably cynical, Techine’s work recalls the strong humanist tradition in French cinema: he is certainly Jean Renoir’s heir. But this is no revisionist or conservative cinema. Techine’s fine intimate portraits are alive to both the possibilities of cinema and the complex sexual and gender relationships at the core of modern life. With Carmen Maura. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Algiers
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Walter Wanger and John Cromwell
results.brief_description: A romantic Casbah thief (Charles Boyer) makes the mistake of falling in love. Hollywood romantic drama based closely on the French original, Pepe le Moko. laughed at for years because of the alleged line `Come with me to the Casbah’ (which was never actually said), it holds up remarkably well in its fashion. Rated: PG
